qas.question: When do Jeffries and Ryan that the modern concept of separation of church and state dates from?
What was the central point of the rulings of the Supreme Court's rulings?

answers.text: constitutional ban against aid to religious schools

qas.question: What was later banned in public education?
How many propositions make up the separationist position on the Establishment Clause?
When don't Jeffries and Ryan that the modern concept of separation of church and state dates from?

plausible_answers.text: constitutional ban against aid to religious schools

qas.question: What was the non-central point of the rulings of the Supreme Court's rulings?
What was later not banned in public education?
How many propositions make up the separationist position on the Non-Establishment Clause?

context: Jeffries and Ryan (2001) argue that the modern concept of separation of church and state dates from the <a0_0><b4_0>mid-twentieth<b4_0/> century<a0_0/> rulings of the Supreme Court. The central point, they argue, was a <a1_0><b5_0>constitutional ban against aid to religious schools<b5_0/><a1_0/>, followed by a later ban on <a2_0><b6_0>religious observance<b6_0/><a2_0/> in public education. Jeffries and Ryan argue that these <a3_0><b7_0>two<b7_0/><a3_0/> propositions—that public aid should not go to religious schools and that public schools should not be religious—make up the separationist position of the modern Establishment Clause.
